thread.title: Boston bike advocates say stop sign law changes are not a priority - Massachusetts news
thread.title_full: Boston bike advocates say stop sign law changes are not a priority - Massachusetts news

author: Adam Vaccaro
title: Boston bike advocates say stop sign law changes are not a priority - Massachusetts news
text:
San Francisco may soon allow bicyclists to merely yield at stop signs, following a cyclist protest of a police crackdown on the practice. According to The New York Times , the proposal—which would need to overcome a veto threat from the city’s mayor—would make San Francisco the largest city in the U.S. to allow so-called Idaho stops, named for the state to have legalized them in the 1980s.
Local cycling advocates have differing opinions on whether they’d like to see rolling stops legalized in and around Boston.
Doug Johnson, a community organizer with the Boston Cyclists Union, said the union would “definitely support” allowing cyclists to roll through stop signs after yielding to traffic and pedestrians, with some exceptions for busy intersections. Johnson said cyclists would benefit from shorter commute times, and drivers may as well .
 “We think, if implemented properly ... it would have no adverse effect on safety,” Johnson said. “Most intersections that have stop signs right now have low traffic volume and low traffic speed.”
Johnson was cooler to the idea of allowing cyclists to ride through red lights after first making a full stop, a practice allowed in Idaho but not proposed in San Francisco, saying the union could only “potentially” get behind that idea.
”It would be a lot more complicated to implement,” he said. “It’s definitely something that would be worth researching.”
But even though the union would support a rule shift, Johnson said it does not consider Idaho stops a priority. San Francisco was ripe for a policy debate because police had targeted stop signs, issuing tickets to violators. Boston cyclists do not currently have such an impetus to take action, he said.
“It got a lot of attention, and they decided to make a stand on it,” Johnson said. “It’s kind of created the political will to create some change there.”
Indeed, it’s hardly a secret of the streets that many cyclists already ride through stop signs and lights, usually without consequence.
MassBike Executive Director Richard Fries said ”would not support” rolling stop rules here, in part for that reason. Boston’s bike culture still has a ways to go before all cyclists are following the existing rules, he said.
“At this point of where we are in bike advocacy, it seems a rather abstract concept,” he said. “We’re still trying to get people to ride the right direction. We would like to see the rules enforced for everyone—cyclists, motorists, pedestrians. The idea of then adding this interpretation of law to the mix is questionable to me.”
Still, Fries said he is interested in seeing what happens in San Francisco.
“If you’re on a bike, there are a lot of intersections where it doesn’t make sense to be at a complete stop,” he said.
Brookline Police flirted with the idea about a year ago when the department asked on Twitter how people would feel about enacting Idaho stop rules, if only during heavy commuting hours or on certain roads. The department later said it was seeking to start a conversation and its rules remained unchanged.
Meanwhile in Boston, it’s unlikely the idea will come to the forefront any time soon.
“No, this has not been considered, but the city of Boston will continue to research and implement policies and practices that make traveling enjoyable, safe and convenient,” said Bonnie McGilpin, a spokeswoman for Mayor Marty Walsh.
The best places to hike in Massachusetts:

R. Cheek Previous -- of -- Next The Parker River Wildlife Refuge in Newburyport is made up of more than 4,700 acres of beach, dunes, cranberry bogs, forest, and freshwater marsh. Flickr/U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Northeast Region Previous -- of -- Next Myles Standish State Forest in South Carver offers 16 ponds, 15 miles of bike trails, 35 miles of equestrian trails, and 13 miles of hiking trails. Flickr/chipmunk_1 Previous -- of -- Next Hike to the highest peak in Massachusetts — 3,491 feet — at Mount Greylock State Reservation in Lanesborough. Flickr/Massachusetts Office of Travel & Tourism Previous -- of -- Next The Appalachian National Scenic Trail spans more than 2,000 miles — and 14 states — between Georgia and Maine. Ninety miles of the trail are in Massachusetts’s Berkshire County. Hop on in North Adams. Flickr/John Hayes Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Hike to the North Bridge at Minute Man National Historic Park in Concord, which marks the spot of the first Revolutionary War battle. Flickr/bbcamericangirl Previous -- of -- Next Trails at Ward Reservation in Andover and North Andover link three major hills: Shrub, Boston, and Holt. These “Solstice Stones” mark the grassy summit of Holt Hill, the highest point in Essex County. R. Reichard Previous -- of -- Next The Skyline Trail at Middlesex Fells Reservation in Medford is a 7-mile jaunt into wilderness located just 30 minutes from the city. Flickr/Lizard10979 Previous -- of -- Next Mass Audubon’s Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary in Topsfield offers 12 miles of trails full of forests, meadows, and wetlands. Flickr/Kristin “Shoe” Shoemaker Previous -- of -- Next The Doyle Estate in Leominster offers 3.5 miles of trails that include woodlands, fields, and formal gardens. Trustees Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Ignore its name and embrace Mount Misery in Lincoln. This circular, well-groomed hike offers views of the Sudbury River and Fairhaven Bay. And the woods were once a favorite spot for Henry David Thoreau. Flickr/liz west Previous -- of -- Next The Acorn Trail at Great Brook Farm State Park in Carlisle is a narrow and winding trail that takes you through fields and woodlands and up a small hill. Flickr/Peter Lee Previous -- of -- Next The Cape Cod National Seashore, which spans the entire eastern shore of Cape Cod, is a great place to hike on the beach. Joanne Rathe/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Gaze at beautiful waterfalls during a hike through Race Brook Falls in Sheffield. You can visit two summits -- Mount Race and Mount Everett (the highest peak in the southern Berkshires). Flickr/Doug Kerr Previous -- of -- Next Blue Hills Reservation, a 6,000-acre state park that stretches from Quincy to Dedham and Milton to Randolph, offers 125 miles of trails. Flickr/Bill Ilott Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Bartholomew’s Cobble in Sheffield, a National Natural Landmark, offers five miles of trails. For more of a challenge, tackle Hurlburt’s Hill, which rises 1,000 feet to a 20-acre upland field with panoramic views on the Massachusetts/Connecticut border. Trustees Previous -- of -- Next Maudslay State Park in Newburyport features 19th century gardens, rolling meadows, and one of the largest naturally-occurring stands of mountain laurel (a species of flowering plant in the heather family) in Massachusetts. Flickr/Kip Voytek Previous -- of -- Next Hike Noanet Woodlands in Dover for great views of Boston, as well as 17 miles of trails. R. Cheek
